response.answer_text: Yes. You’re enlightened. This is the correct answer. Seven billion people growl to disagree. “Don’t tell me I’m enlightened — makes me angry.”“Me? Enlightened? I’m working off bad karma from thousands of lifetimes.”“Nope. Not me. I don’t witness my dreams. My waking mind is a hot mess.”“I’ve never done anything spiritual or religious. Enlightenment isn’t real.”“I’m a PhD in psychology. Get out of here with that silly religious stuff.”“I love God and pray daily, but I’m a sinner and far from being a saint.”“I’ve done bad things. No way am I salvageable. I don’t deserve enlightenment.” Etc.So what gives? How can a guru say, “everyone’s enlightened” and keep a straight face? Answer: A guru sees God at play when you project identity. The actor, Boris Karloff, pretended to be Dr. Frankenstein’s monster. Back stage, everyone knew him to be a gentleman to great degree.Not a single sin of the monster was the karma of Boris.Same deal for you. You can realize that you’re an actor. You can realize that your role is not you.You can realize that God wrote the script. So see how easy it is to stop being a mistaken identity? You don’t have to adjust the script. The play continues.You don’t have to make the monster become moral.You don’t have to understand the monster.You don’t have to get the monster to start meditating. You don’t have to have a relationship with The Playwright. Instead:— take a break.— go backstage.— remove your wig. How? Closing the eyes is all the “method acting” you need. When we close the eyes, we’re immediately backstage. We now see:— There’s a mental play being performed. The mind is theatrical. — Thoughts and emotions are strutting and fretting their hour. — One attends no matter if it’s a comedy or tragedy. If we practice meditation, we are gradually freed. Once freed of thinking one is one’s role, the whole theater is realized.Once the theater is seen, outside the theater can be explored. Outside the mind is pure God.God swaddles creation like a newborn infant.In every manner, we are escorted by silence, God’s Being. Any closing of the eyes brings God’s Being to the fore.Silence is suddenly huge. Expansive beyond one’s skull. As we practice being silent we begin to be silence, God’s Being.Silence gradually becomes enlivened to an all time reality. After that, God’s being is your elixir.After that, God’s writing your lines.After that, God’s speaking your words. After that, God’s two hands are heard clapping.

This state is called stability of mind. You should not stop your sadhana continue it. This is not enlightenment or Nirvaana or Samadhi. You are travelling towards God. This is a very good experience. We have two types of Samadhi: Sampragyata Samadhi or Savikalpa Samadhi: In this type of Samadhi you will know that the Meditator,Meditation and whom to meditate are not absorbed but the consciousness becomes calm or silent and that consciousness stand in Brahman is Sampragyata Samadhi.This state is like a dawn of the day which mean sunlight exhibited without appearance of Sun.In this state the eternal happiness is experienced but not at the appearance of the Atman.In this state, Self-realization is not attained. The state of mind is like a cat on the wall which mean it endeavors to get absorbed in to Samadhi.In this Samadhi, Mind attains the state of consciousness but self-realization is not attained.Seeker in this state should practice a lot to get the state of Enlightenment.Asampragyata Samadhi or NirvikalpaSamadhi or Enlightenment: This is the state of man becoming God.In this state man as Brahman exists, No Meditation, Meditator or meditation on whom does not exist.This Samadhi is like a Sun Rise which mean lustre accompanied by Sun appearance.In this Samadhi eternal happiness is accompanied by enlightenment.Sunlight and Sun cannot get isolated like wise the eternal happiness and enlightenment cannot get isolated in this state.Every human being is enjoying eternal happiness in his daily life but due to inexperience of the Samadhi he is unable to identify it. For example. when we perform a deed with concentration or listening to a music, or when we are with a peace of mind. when we see few astonishing movements we experience this state.The above cannot be comprehended unless we experience the state of samadhi.When we listen to music, our eyes get closed efoortlessly, our mind becoms conscious of listening music, we experience a state of happiness. This is “Shabdanu viddhi Samadhi”.When we watch a person performing cultural dance, we forget every thing and watch it. This is “Drushyanu Viddhi Samadhi”.

Of course, not. In my understand, there will be no doubt or confusion after achieving even the stage of stream-winner, (Sotāpanna in Pali and Srotāpanna in Sanskrit), which is the very first step or the very first achievement in the journey of Enlightenment. Now, you are asking whether you are enlightened or not.  Don't believe what I said. You can question, challenges, test and understand by following steps what Buddha has outlined. There are people who does not take the achievement of stream-winner because they want to achieve the full Buddhahood so that they can also liberate others. I will discuss about different kinds of liberators later. Achieving the first stage: Stream-winner Once you achieve even the first stage, i.e., Stream-winner or stream-enterer, you have already cuts off the first three of ten fetters[1], which catch us into the circle of life and death. These three fetters are (1) belief in a self, i.e., believing that we have an eternal soul; (2) doubt or uncertainty, especially about the Dharma or teachings, i.e., about the laws of nature and life taught or shared by Buddha, which includes the Four Noble Truths and the Eightfold Path. What does a Stream-winner mean?Once we achieve that stream-winner stage, we will be liberated, i.e., escaping from the circles of life and death, within next seven lives. We will never be again in the low four plains of existence[2]. According to Buddhism, Stream-enterer attains an intuitive grasp of dharma (right view) and has complete confidence in the Three Jewels (Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha). He or she has "opened the eye of the Dharma", because he or she has realized that whatever arises will cease (impermanence). Their conviction in the true dharma would be unshakable. Most importantly, stream-enterers never commit the five precepts[3], which is the very basic in Buddhist practices.  Four stages of attainment In the journey of enlightenment there are four stages we have to achieve; first, Stream-enterer (we have already discussed about it); second, Once-returner; third, Non-returner; and, fourth, Arahant.  According to Buddhism, everyone who truly achieves that kind of stage keep their achievements in secret. I will talk about it more later. I will also give full references for what I have said. Please help me: how can I stay away from Quora just for a couple of days until I finish all my assignments? I think it is also a kind of attachment that Buddha wants us to release ourselves from it. Footnotes [1] Ten "fetters of becoming"(1) belief in a self (2) doubt or uncertainty, especially about the Dhamma or teachings(3) attachment to rites and rituals (4) sensual desire (5) ill will (6) lust for material existence, lust for material rebirth(7) lust for immaterial existence, lust for rebirth in a formless realm(8) conceit (9) restlessness(10) ignorance [2] There are in total 31 planes of existence, according to Buddhism. [3] Five Precepts of Buddhism(1) Not killing, that includes killing all kinds of living beings(2) not taking what is not given, i.e., stealing(3) not conducting or having sexual misconduct, like adultery and having sex out of marriage, rape, etc(4) not giving false speech, i.e., lying, or telling of lies, or false statements, or untruthfulness(5) not taking fermented drink that causes heedlessness, i.e., not drinking alcohol or alcoholic drink, not taking drug

It might be a state you enter that is out of the ordinary, not like your usual experience. Those states, if they come and go, can’t be enlightenment. Enlightenment can’t be a product of causes, can’t come and go. It is supremely ordinary in a way :). “It is incorrect to think that Nirvāṇa is the natural result of the extinction of craving. Nirvāṇa is not the result of anything. If it would be a result, then it would be an effect produced by a cause. It would be saṃkhata ‘produced’ and ‘conditioned’. Nirvāṇa is neither cause nor effect. It is beyond cause and effect. Truth is not a result nor an effect. It is not produced like a mystic, spiritual, mental state, such as dhyāna or samādhi. TRUTH IS. NIRVĀṆA IS. The only thing you can do is to see it, to realize it. There is a path leading to the realization of Nirvāṇa. But Nirvāṇa is not the result of this path You may get to the mountain along a path, but the mountain is not the result, not an effect of the path. You may see a light, but the light not the result of your eyesight.” The Third Noble Truth - Walpola Rahula: What the Buddha Taught But sometimes these states do carry something of the message or blessings of enlightenment. Other times they are just distractions. Either way, where it can go wrong is if you start to try to find ways to reproduce it. Once it becomes a state you try to reproduce, it becomes an effect you are trying to cause. It becomes like a child hitting their head against a wall to try to se stars. Once that happens, then you can spiral into hitting your head harder and harder until you see really bright stars - that’s doing nobody any good. Even if it is genuinely carrying something of the message of non self or enlightenment or whatever it is. Generally the best thing to do when you get unusual experiences that seem in some way “spiritual” is to just recognize them as experiences. Okay today I stubbed my toe. And yesterday I got this unusual state of mind I’ve never encountered before. Just accept them both as states that arise, and then pass away. A good teacher would help you there, how to deal with it. There may be a message sometimes of some sort. If so, well it will come back in its own time. A good teacher may help you in other ways at this point. But it’s not easy to do much yourself, because as soon as you feel you can achieve something using this experience, that becomes a spiritual accomplishment, or something you create and possess, which for a Buddhist anyway - that’s leading you away from the path. A teacher helps by being someone else who is not you who can lead you in a fresh direction, but it’s very hard to do that at that point by yourself. Basically you need a sense of humour. Okay I’m bound to get funny states from time to time. And sometimes I’m bound to start treating them and myself as special because of those states. This happens to everyone at some point if they do any work with their mind including meditation or just deep contemplation. Can happen sometimes from listening to music, or art, or just looking at a flower. Indeed in some traditions they say these sorts of experiences are happening all the time, but we just don’t notice it or immediately forget them. There’s nothing special about any of it. Nor is there anything special about enlightenment. In some traditions again the ay they put this is that the number of Buddhas way outnumbers ordinary beings. Nearly everyone is enlightened already and we are the few dumb ones left who have somehow not managed to “get it” after countless trillions of lifetimes. That thought can help one to not treat such experiences as special, and to maybe be open to the path and to finding a direction. While if you treat them as special you’ll maybe never get any closer. It can become a very big impediment indeed for those who fixate too much on it. My teacher once told us that the sickness of clinging to illusory ideas of self is difficult to deal with - but the sickness of clinging to illusory realizations of non self is extremely hard to deal with - because you have turned the medicine that could cure you into a sickneses itself. So, it just needs a light touch. Which is where a teacher can really help, that’s one of the main roles of a teacher I think. I don’t mean a guru though that is also the main role of a guru too if I understand it right (I don’t have a guru) - but just a teacher who is not yourself. can help a lot. Without a teacher, just a sense of humour and a light touch will help a lot. If you haven’t read Walpola Rahula’s little book “What the Buddha taught” you may find it helps a lot to be a bit more grounded about such things. The Third Noble Truth - Walpola Rahula: What the Buddha Taught

Asking the question is answering it. I once had an experience that made a huge impact on me, over a decade ago. I thought I got 'there'. I didn't question the experience and at first also not the meaning. After a couple of days stress set in. How does one get stress from something good, awesome? First of all, very soon a background realisation hit: it cannot last. It was never in front, only in the background. Next was that it was impossible to talk about with people. I could explain parts of the experience yet it felt too 'alien' to fully talk. I could not get it verified and would often receive blank stares when talking a little. Years later a second experience. This one was quite different. With the first experience it took me a long time to figure out what happened. This one was directly linked to meditation and right afterwards I knew what happened and its implications. The question of 'realisation/enlightenment' was not a question anymore. Self and non-self, no more doubts what this means. Also within seconds after standing up the realisation: 'this cannot last'. Since the mind was quiet at that moment it was like being struck by lightning: where did that come from?This bit kept me wondering for months because the experience was such that I know the resulting peace is always present. It has to be. A quick recall will drop the mind into the peaceful state in a split second. One day while sitting in meditation the mind began to stir and the source of the earlier wondering became apparent. I've encountered many different states of mind in meditation and would have never expected this one.  Why am I telling this?There are many experiences and you can assign different meanings to them. After the first experience I had a similar mindset as you and it took me over a decade to get past it. Only afterwards I was able to pick up the vigorous training leading to the second experience. I could have gotten stuck on the peace of that state easily. The best advice I can give you is the same as Armin's: seek a teacher.I didn't have good guidance after my first experience and it plunged me into several depressions after a couple of years. I've met my 'teacher' in a way I would have never expected and only after meeting my teacher I was able to get a grip on myself and start moving into the right direction. And it hurt a lot, even though I already knew things were 'not real' so to speak. You need to understand that in the background some things are at play of which I can give only very limited guidance in a medium as the internet. Only when staying close to someone these traits become clear. The internet is not the right place to go into this, it's easy to make mistakes due to the delayed communication which lacks any form of personal interaction.Really, seek a teacher.  Oh, by the way. If things are only sounds, not-self and have no real meaning: Take a large hammer. Put your thumb on the table. Pick hammer with other hand. Lift hammer and with full force bring it down on your thumb. There is no truth behind the experience, so why don't you do it?

Ther are many different paths though and you may want to find one that resonates best with you.  ...The difference between Nirvikalpa Samádhi and Savikalpa Samádhi is that during Nivikalpa Samádhi (total suspension of the mind, or trance of Complete Absorption) the unit mind merges in the Supreme Puruśa, and that is why, in that condition, Bhoga (pleasure and pain), Bhogya (that which is to be undergone or perceived) and Bhoktá (the perceiver), or Jiṋána (Knowledge), Jineya (Knowable) and Jiṋátabháva (Knowership) do not exist. There remains only an unexpressed Bliss-Entity, whose perceiver remains self-lost in ecstasy, completely oblivious of what he or she will get. Such a condition of the unit entities does not last long either. The Mutative Principle of Prakrti will bring them back to their unit-hood or microcosmic state in order to undergo and serve the unserved Saḿskáras. Thus returning to their individuality they feel as though some inexhaustible spring of ecstatic exhilaration of some unknown region is inundating their mind, their soul, their entire entity. – Abhávottaránandapratyayálambaniivrttirtasy apramáńam.–Ánanda Sútram After that sense of void when the tide of happiness floods the mind, then one can understand that, that so-called state of want or void was nothing but Nirvikalpa Samádhi (The void, because, in the absence of the mind there was no matter or object). The question of breach of, or return from Savikalpa or Nirvikalpa does not arise in the case of one who has no remnant of Saḿskára to serve. Such a lasting Savikalpa is called Mukti or liberation and such a lasting Nirvikalpa is called Mokśa or final beatitude – salvation. You must have thoroughly understood these two through Ananda Marga way of Sádhaná... Also see the comment to the comment below.

“Enlightened” is a loaded word these days. So let’s define terms. In truth, it’s best to think of the path to enlightenment (or self-realization or self-actualization) as a scale. Picture a ruler. Now imagine one end doesn’t end. Instead, it extends to infinity in that direction. Now picture the other end extending to infinity too. That’s the path to enlightenment. We’re all on it because we’re all divine beings. We’re just in different places on it. Also, since there is no “end,” there is no moment when we can say “I am enlightened” really. If we commit to the path we’ll move up the scale and become more enlightened. Our experience of ourselves and our lives will change then too. Maybe we’ll add some amazing power or ability we didn’t have before. Surely then we are more enlightened than we were and than most people. So, congratulations…You are enlightened! And you have wonderful opportunities to continue your journey ahead of you! (As do I!) B.

No you are not enlightened. If you were, you would see reality as it is, and wouldn't need to ask on Quora if you were enlightened. When the Buddha attained enlightenment he knew exactly what he had done, but initially doubted he could communicate it to others because it was beyond the understanding of the unenlightened.The simplest way to check for enlightenment is to see if you ever experience negative mental states. If you do, you're definitely not enlightened (although if you don't, that doesn't prove you are enlightened).However, what you describe does sound like a very advanced spiritual state - insight. Possibly stream entry. Insight is when a practitioner gains some understanding of the nature of reality (as in truly seeing the nature of things rather than just knowing theoretically about emptiness etc). Stream entry is when someone has had enough insight that there is no chance of them falling away from the path, and enlightenment is inevitable. However, even a stream entrant can experience negative mental states until they gain full enlightenment.You've clearly had a major breakthrough - keep doing whatever you are doing!

Don’t know. Enlightenment is not just a clear mind, in the present moment, and there is no ‘self’ (taken from the additional info of this question)…enlightenment also means the cessation of dukkha (ala the Buddha’s Four Noble Truths). Dukkha is discontentment and suffering. Has dissatisfaction and discontentment with life, the world, etc. ceased? Has suffering like fear, guilt, boredom, etc. ceased? Time will reveal this answer too, because enlightenment does not come and go. If suddenly there is belief in a “me” again…and so suffering, attachment, etc. - then it was a passing glimpse or spiritual experience. If this happens, what is still missing is understanding. For enlightenment is dispelling ignorance (via understanding) and no longer being fooled by the illusion…if the illusion still causes confusion in future, it has not yet been seen through because understanding is still lacking.

I think you have entered the path, the first of many steps to enlightenment, and that you should find a teacher, or two or three, and give it time. I personally would avoid much Buddhist approach for reasons of form over substance, obsessions with dogmatic acceptance using a foreign vocabulary, where many of its adherents spend the bulk of their time telling each other that they are wrong, unless you are Indian or Chinese, in which case this would be fine. If, however, you grew up Western, there are far better teachers that will make sense to you and not send you into needless circles for a decade. It sounds like you already started with ACIM, if so, take one year off and do the lessons again. Read Joseph Campbell, Regina Dawn Akers, Byron Katie, Adyashanti, Francis Bennett, as a starting point. There are at least another 100 that these might point you toward, if you are interested, or any of these may have the depth or approach that you want to continue. Another year of contemplative meditation and you will reach an awareness that they are all saying the same thing with different words, then you are truly ready to live it, for Enlightenment, or Awakening as I prefer to call it, is not something intellectual, as knowledge of what is True cannot be taught nor does it have value in its own right, it is merely what we call it when a person is living in the world but not of the world, seeing past the appearances of separation, someone who has discovered who they truly are, and hardly makes decisions with any involvement of their, now greatly diminished, egoic self. This person will demonstrate an acceptance of all, little attachment to the material, automatic trust, forgiveness, joy, patience, generosity, defenselessness, honesty, tolerance, faithfulness, openmindedness, and unconditional love of others.  Good luck in your next steps. Blessings!

I’ve been doing Buddhist vipassana insight mindfulness meditation and what you are experiencing sounds like what I experienced in some Buddhist meditation retreats. It’s possible that you are a reborn Stream-enterer who has attained the first of the levels of realizing Nibbana (Nirvana) in your last life. I’ve met a lady who is one of those and been told about others. Have you avoided killing even bugs all your life? This was the case with Gloria Ambrosia an Italian American women who was found sitting in full lotus posture as a very little girl by her non-Buddhist parents. She even as a young child never killed a bug having the natural keeping of the moral precepts of a Stream-enterer. I would seek out an advanced teacher of Theravada Buddhist insight mindfulness meditation vipassana. Gloria Ambrosia does teachings at the IMS Buddhist retreat center in Barre Massachusetts and is associated with the Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery in California. You could try to contact her through them.  In Buddhist insight meditation one sees the impermanence and no-Self nature of the observing consciousness as well as the object. The higher consciousness of concentration meditation is a temporary liberation only Nirvana gained through insight mindfulness vipassana meditation is a permanent liberation. Gloria is giving a vipassana meditation retreat at the Albuquerque Vipassana Sangha (Albuquerque, New Mexico) on  October 19 - November 4. If you can get off work I would encourage you to go to her retreat if there still is an opening.

Attainment of the Supramundane paths is a momentary experience that is always followed by direct recognition of Nirvana.  It's a powerful experience that can resonate in us even weeks after.  Attainment of each Path is usually thought to occur in single steps, although there's no rule for this and more than one step could be achieved at one time. Attainment is usually possible through high levels of concentration, but this also need not happen only to meditators.  Samadhi has been known to occur spontaneously (see Zen and the Sudden Schools).  Samadhi has its own symptoms of deep ease and, most importantly, it facilitates clear comprehension. Fortunate indeed if you attained the Supramundane and not merely Samadhi (which can also resonate its peace and clarity for a long time).  If the Supramundane was reached you will know once your new reorientation with reality settles.  That takes time.  The shock of attainment can be a very confusing time, but once the concentration does wane, and it will, you will be able to recognize better how far you traveled through the arising of surviving fetters.

Yes, you are enlightened, whether you like it or not, whether you believe it or not. The only barrier to being enlightened is whether you allow it or not! Please do not heed any answers that declare you are not enlightened, or you are awakened but not enlightened, or you are half-way there, etc BS.  From your post, it seems you have allowed it. It comes and goes - just like the breath. There is no holding it. Just be - you are it.

If you have to ask, probably not.  What is your relationship to greed, hatred and delusion? Check out What Does It Mean To Be Enlightened?  I'd say you have had some kind of direct experience of sunyata, or emptiness. Also, you may have reached some kind of understanding of the five aggregates.  Find others who've had similar experiences, and compare notes.

Do you have ready access to the common human goal - peace-of-mind? Can you pause for a moment and become aware of an onrush of bliss? Does contentment underpin your every waking moment?
